tgt_text.2615: Unter solch edlen Bestrebungen, in welchen er auch seine Söhne erzog, wünscht der Sohn des Kleonikos, Lam­ Pon, bis in's Greisenalter zu leben und zu sterben.
tgt_text.2616: Klotho, eine der drei Motten, der Göttinnen des Schicksals.Der Dichter nennt die Gränzen der Erde gegen Norden und Süden, indem er den ganzen Erdkreis umfassen will.Von ihm, dem Vater, dem Telamon, der dem Herakles in den ersten troischen Krieg folgte, um den Betrug des Laomedon zu rächen.
tgt_text.2617: Aus demselben Zuge wurden auch die Meroper auf Kos und der thrakifche Riese Alkyoneus im Phlegräischen Gefilde bezwungen.
tgt_text.2618: Thiersch.Die Erzählung lenkt hier wieder aus den Anfang (V. 31.) zurück, um weiter auszuholen.Eriböa heißt die Mutter des Ajas auch bei Sophokles (im rasenden Ajas);
tgt_text.2619: Andere nennen sie anders.Pindar leitet den Namen Ajas von Aietos (Adler) ab, Sophokles von dem Wehruf:
tgt_text.2620: Ai, Ai!Euthymenes, Sohn des Themistios (V. 75), der Mutter- bruder des siegreichen Brüderpaares.Die Ioner sind von langer Rede, von kurzer aber nicht nur die Lakoner, sondern auch die Argeier.
tgt_text.2621: Der Scholiast.Die Psalychiden, eine Zunft in Aegina, zu welcher das Haus der Sieger gehörte.,, Sorgfalt fördert die Werke", sagt Hesiodos in den Hauslehren.
tgt_text.2622: Lampon selbst kämpfte nicht, ließ aber seine Söhne mit großer Sorgfalt unterweisen, weßhalb der Dichter sagt, daß er an jenem Worte des Hesiodos mit Eifer festhalte, und ihn V. 83 f. ǧden Wezstein für Ringer" nennt, und zwar den von Naxos;
tgt_text.2623: ǧdenn", bemerkt der Scholiast, ǧvor allen anderen Wezsteinen werden die auf Naxos in Kreta für die ausgezeichnetsten gehalten.
tgt_text.2625: Die heiligen Fluten Dirka's, welche die Musen schöpfen, sind des Dichters Lied.
tgt_text.2626: Pindar wohnte an der Dirke vor dem neitischen Thore.Theba ist die Nymphe der Stadt, die als die Zeugin der ǧfrüheren Zierden" Thebe's angeredet wird.
tgt_text.2627: Demeter (oder Deo) heißt die erznmrauschte wegen der bei ihrem Feste ertönenden Cymbeln.
tgt_text.2628: Denn mit Cymbeln und Pauken zog die Göttin umher und erregte Geräusch mit ihnen, auf daß Alle hörten und vernahmen, was sie suchte (nämlich die verlorene Tochter Persephone).
tgt_text.2629: Beisizer (Genossen) der Demeter aber nennt er den Dio­ nysos nach der mystischen Sage, weil ihr der aus Per­ sephone geborene Zagreus Dionysos gesellt wird, der nach Einigen Jakchos ist.
tgt_text.2630: Der Scholiast.Die Sage von der Danae, zu welcher Zeus im Gold­ regen kam, wird hier aus Alkmene übergetragen.
tgt_text.2631: Drachensaat heißen die Theber, weil ihre Vorfahren aus den von Kadmos ausgesäten Drachenzähnen von der Erde um Theben hervorgebracht wurden.
tgt_text.2632: Der SchobDie Aegiden sind ein Stamm in Thebe, von dem ein Theil, gerufen in Folge eines pythischen Spruches, nach Sparta auszog, den Lakedämoniern in dem Kriege gegen die Amykläer unter Anführung des Timomachos zu helfen, welcher die Lakedämonier zuerst in Allem, was zum Kriege gehört, unterrichtete, und bei ihnen großer Ehren ge­ würdigt ist.
tgt_text.2633: Auch wird am Feste der Hyakinthien sein goldener Panzer gezeigt.
tgt_text.2634: Der Schol.Diodotos hieß der Vater des älteren Strepsiades, welcher in der dreitägigen Schlacht bei Oenophyta fiel, ǧpreisend den Hektor und Meleagros und Amphiaraos", d. i. lobend ihren rüstigen Muth und ihm nacheifernd, da auch sie im Kampfe für ihr Vaterland fielen, das mit ihnen zu­ gleich in den Staub sank.Nicht in eigenem Namen spricht hier der Dichter, sondern im Namen des Chores, der, weil er einen Sieg nach schwerer Niederlage feiert, sich mit Kränzen geschmückt hat, und am Schlüsse des Gesanges den Apollon um einen pythischen Sieg anruft.Daß die Schmach von Hellas abgewandt ist, hat meinen schweren Kummer gestillt.
tgt_text.2635: Wohl ziemt es, sich immer das Nächste zu beachten, die Gegenwart festzuhalten, und diese kann wegen der Siegesfeier des Kleandros nur zur Freude stimmen.
tgt_text.2636: Denn die Zukunft ist unsicher und trügerisch.
tgt_text.2637: Was aber auch die Zeit über uns verhängt hat, auch diese Wunden sind heilbar, da die Freiheit gerettet ist.
tgt_text.2638: Darum ziemt es sich Hoffnung und Ver­ trauen zu fassen, dem Theber aber noch besonders Ae­ gina zu feiern, weil Theba und Aegina Schwestern sind, V. 29 ff.Theba und Aegina waren die jüngeren Töchter des böo­ tischen Flusses Asopos.
tgt_text.2639: Denn vor ihnen, bemerkt ein alter Ausleger, war noch Metope geboren und andere..
tgt_text.2640: Oenona oder Oenopia, der alte Name der Insel Aegina.Der Dichter berührt hier eine sonst unbekannte Sage, nach welcher Aeakos als Schiedsrichter unter streitenden Göttern auftrat
tgt_text.2641: .Das Schicksal bestimmte der Thetis einen Sohn, der mächtiger sein würde, als sein Vater.
tgt_text.2642: Wenn nun Zeus oder ein anderer Kronide sich ihr vermählte, so stürzte der Sprößling aus dieser Ehe die Macht des Zeus, und herrschte an seiner Statt.
tgt_text.2643: Themis kennt diesen Rath des Schicksals, und durch sie Prometheus bei Aeschylos.
tgt_text.2644: Er, ist das Geheimniß dieses Titanen, welches Zeus umsonst ihm zu entreißen sucht, dessen Enthüllung einst das Unter­ pfand seiner Versöhnung mit ihm sein wird.
tgt_text.2645: Nach Pindar aber wird es den Göttern von Themis enthüllt, die dann den Rath gibt, Thetis dem gerechtesten der Sterblichen, dem Pelens, zu vermählen.
tgt_text.2646: Zwar wird auch aus dieser Ehe ein Sohn, stärker als sein Vater, entspringen, aber den Göttern nicht gefährlich und bestimmt, im Kampfe zu fallen.
tgt_text.2647: Thiersch.Peleus hatte Jolkos im Kriege gegen Akastos erobert.Zur Grotte des Cheiron geht die Kunde, weil dort in Gegenwart aller Götter die Vermählung gefeiert werden soll.Zeus ordnete selbst mit Cheiron das Brautfest, daß nämlich die Götter selbst bei der Feier erschienen, Apollon mit den Musen das Brautlied sang, und die Unsterblichen dem neuvermählten Paare Geschenke brachten.
tgt_text.2648: Nicht unmittelbar befreite Achilleus Helenen, aber er ward Ursache ihrer Befreiung, indem er durch seine glück­ lichen Gefechte die Macht der Troer schwächte, den tapfersten Troer, Hektor, erschlug, und dadurch die Eroberung Troja's erleichterte
tgt_text.2649: .Die Sehnen Troja's sind die gleich nachher genannten Haupthelden der Troer, die vom Speer des Achilleus erlegt wurden.
tgt_text.2650: Dorisch heißt der Eppichkranz in Beziehung auf den ko­ rinthischen Isthmos, wo Griechen dorischer Abkunft wohnten
tgt_text.2651: .Der Sohn des Oheims des Nikokles ist Kleandros.
tgt_text.2652: Alkathoos, ein Sohn des Pelops, hatte nach Erlegung des kithäronischen Löwen, dem Apollon zu Ehren, in Megara Kampfspiele gestiftet:
tgt_text.2654: !, Hl-Die Kampfspiele zu Epidauros in Argolis waren dem Asklepios geweiht.Gedruckt bei E. Polz in Leipzig.
tgt_text.2655: Seite 22 Zeile 4 für erhht l. erhöht.

tgt_text.0: IN preparing the following prose translation, I have endear­ voured to exhibit such a rendering of the text as I should myself have been glad to have, when preparing for a Uni­ versity Examination.
tgt_text.1: Any one who is at all acquainted with the difficulty of the author, will readily pardon my having in no case ventured to substitute any phraseology of my own for what I be­ lieved to be the literal meaning.
tgt_text.2: I have to express the greatest possible obligations to the commentaries of Boeckh and Dissen, but for the assistance of which I should hardly have ventured on my present task.
tgt_text.3: Many thanks are also due for the aid afforded by Mr. Cookesley's excellent notes, as well as those of Dr. Donald­ son.
tgt_text.4: I have, I trust, in every instance, acknowledged my obligations.
tgt_text.5: If I have in any degree succeeded in presenting the student with a not-unworthy representation of Pindar's meaning, the merit is mainly to be attributed to these resources and to the great kindness of three excellent friends, the Rev. J. Lonsdale, M.A., Fellow of Balliol College, Oxford;
tgt_text.6: the Rev. John G. Sheppard, M.A., 2nd Master of Repton School, and late Fellow of Wadham College ;
tgt_text.7: and Mr. J. LL Davies, B.A., Fellow of Trinity College, Cam­ bridge ;
tgt_text.8: who have given me the benefit of their revision and correction throughout the whole work.
tgt_text.9: With the few exceptions pointed out as they occur, I have followed the text of Bergk, from whom the Prefaces also are taken.
tgt_text.10: Dr. Donaldson had set me the example of adopting the Introductions of the Odes from Dissen's Commentary.
tgt_text.11: SINCE the prose portion of this volume was completed, the publisher has obtained permission from the executors of the late Mr. Abraham Moore to reprint his excellent metrical version, and accordingly has the pleasure of adjoining it.
tgt_text.12: As this version is distinguished for poetry, scholarship, and taste, and is besides among the rarest and most expensive volumes of our modern literature, the literary public will have reason to be satisfied with its reproduction on such advantageous terms.
tgt_text.14: Olympic Festival was a Pentaeteris (πενταευηρίς), that in.
tgt_text.15: according to the ancient mode of reckoning, a space of four years elapsed between each festival, in the same way as there was only a space of two years between a Trieteris.
tgt_text.16: It was celebrated on the first full moon after the summer sol­ stice.
tgt_text.17: It lasted, after all the contests had been introduced, five days, fromthe 11th to the 15th days of the month inclusive.
tgt_text.18: The fourth day of the festival was the 14th of the month, which was the day of the full moon, and which divided the month into two equal parts.
tgt_text.19: The festival was under the immediate superintendence of the Olympian Zeus, whose temple at Olympia, adorned with the statue of the god made by Phidias, was one of the most splendid works of art in Greece.
tgt_text.20: There were also temples and altars to other gods.
tgt_text.21: The festival itself may be divided into two parts-the games or contests (ἀγὼν 'Ολυμπιακός), and the festive rites (ἑορτή);
tgt_text.22: connected with the sacrifices, with the processions, and with the public banquets in honour of the conquerors.
tgt_text.23: The contests consisted of various trials of strength and skill, which were increased in number from time to time.
tgt_text.24: There were in all twenty-four contests, eighteen in which men took part, and six in which boys engaged, though they were never all exhibited at one festival, since some were abolished almost immediately after their institution, and others after they had been in use only a short time.
tgt_text.25: We subjoin a list of these from Pausanias, with the date of introduction of each, commencing from the Olympiad of Coræbus :
tgt_text.27: The foot-race (δρόμος), which was the only contest during the first 13 Olympiads.
tgt_text.29: The δίαυλος, or foot-race, in which the stadium was traversed twice, first introduced in Olympiad 14.
tgt_text.31: The δόλιχος, a still longer foot-race than the δίαυλος, introduced in Olympiad 15.
tgt_text.34: The Pentathlum (πένταθλον), which consisted of five exercises, viz.
tgt_text.35: leaping, the foot-race, the throwing the discus, the throwing the spear, and wrestling;
tgt_text.38: 7th. The chariot-race, with four full-grown horses (ἵππων τελείων δρόμος, ἅρμα), introduced in Olympiad 25.
tgt_text.39: 8th. The Pancratium (παγκρά­ ιον), consisting of boxing and wrestling;
tgt_text.41: The horse-race (ἵππος κέλης), both introduced in Olympiad 33.
tgt_text.43: The foot-race and wrestling for boys, intro­ duced in Olympiad 37.
tgt_text.45: The Pentathlum for boys, introduced in Olympiad 38, but immediately afterwards abolished.
tgt_text.46: 13th. Boxing for boys, introduced in Olym piad 41.
tgt_text.48: The foot-race, in which men ran with the equipments of heavy-armed soldiers (τω̃νὁπλιτω̃ν δρόμος), introduced in Olympiad 65, on account of its training men for actual service in war.
tgt_text.50: The chariot-race -with mules (ἀπήνη), introduced in Olympiad 70;
tgt_text.52: The horse-race with mares (κάλπη), introduced in Olympiad 71 ;
tgt_text.53: both of which were abolished in Olympiad 84.
tgt_text.55: The chariot-race with two full-grown horses (ἵππων τελείων συνωρίς), introduced in Olympiad 93.
tgt_text.57: The contests of heralds (κήρυκες) and trumpeters (σαλπιγκταί), introduced in Olympiad 96.
tgt_text.59: The chariot-race with four foals (πώλων ἅρμασιν), introduced in Olympiad 99.
tgt_text.61: The chariot-race with two foals (πώλων συνωρίς), intro­ duced in Olympiad 128.
tgt_text.63: The horse-race with foals (πώλος κέλης), introduced in Olympiad 131.
tgt_text.65: The Pancratium for boys, introduced in Olympiad 145.
tgt_text.67: There was also a horse-race (ἵππος κέλης), in which boys rode, but we do not know the time of its introduction.
tgt_text.68: The judges in the Olympic Games, called Hellanodicæ ('Ελλανοδίκαι), were appointed by the Eleans, who had the regulation of the whole festival.
tgt_text.69: It appears to have been originally under the superintendence of Pisa, in the neigh­ bourhood of which Olympia was situated;
tgt_text.70: but after the conquest of Peloponnesus by the Dorians, on the return of the Heraclidæ, the Ætolians, who had been of great assist­ ance to the Heraclidæ, settled in Elis, and from this time the Ætolian Eleans obtained the regulation of the festival, and appointed the presiding officers.
tgt_text.71: The Hellanodicæ were chosen by lot from the whole body of the Eleans.
tgt_text.72: Their number varied at different periods, but at a later time there were eight Hellanodicæ.
tgt_text.73: The office, probably, lasted for only one festival.
tgt_text.74: They had to see that all the laws relating to the games were observed by the competitors and others, to determine the prizes and to give them to the conquerors.
tgt_text.75: An appeal lay from their decision to the Elean senate.
tgt_text.76: Under the direction of the Hel­ lanodicæ were a certain number of Alytæ (ἀλύται), with an Alytarches (ἀλυτάρχης) at their head, who formed a kind of police, and carried into execution the commands of the Hellanodicæ.
tgt_text.77: There were also various other minor officers under the control of the Hellanodicæ.
tgt_text.78: All free Greeks were allowed to contend in the games, who had complied with the rules prescribed to candidates.
tgt_text.79: The equestrian contests were necessarily confined to the wealthy;
tgt_text.80: but the poorest citizens could contend in the athletic games.
tgt_text.81: This, however, was far from degrading the games in public opinion;
tgt_text.82: and some of the noblest as well as meanest citizens of the state took part in these contests.
tgt_text.83: The owners of the chariots and horses were not obliged to contend in pe ;
tgt_text.84: and the wealthy vied with one another in the number and magnificence of the chariots and horses which they sent to the games.
tgt_text.85: All persons who were about to contend, had to prove to the Hellanodicæ that they were freemen, and of pure Hel­ lenic blood;
tgt_text.86: that they had not been branded with atimia, nor guilty of any sacrilegious act.
tgt_text.87: They further had to prove that they had undergone the preparatory training (πργυμνάσματα) for ten months previously.
tgt_text.88: All competitors were obliged, thirty days before the festival, to undergo certain exercises in the Gymnasium, at Elis, under the super­ intendence of the Hellanodicæ.
tgt_text.89: The competitors took their places by lot.
tgt_text.90: The herald then proclaimed the name and country of each competitor.
tgt_text.91: When they were all ready to begin the contest, the judges exhorted them to acquit them­ selves nobly, and then gave the signal to commence.
tgt_text.92: The only prize given to the conqueror was a garland of wild olive (κότιος), cut from a sacred olive-tree, which grew in the sacred grove of Altis, in Olympia.
tgt_text.93: The victor was originally crowned upon a tripod covered over with bronze, but after­ wards upon a table made of ivory and gold.
tgt_text.95: the common tokens of victory on other occasions, were placed in his hands.
tgt_text.96: The name of the victor, and that of his father and of his country, were then proclaimed by a herald before the representatives of assembled Greece.
tgt_text.97: The festival ended with processions and sacrifices, and with a public banquet given by the Eleans to the conquerors in the Prytaneium.
tgt_text.98: The most powerful states considered an Olympic victory, gained by one of their citizens, to confer honour upon the state to whic' he belonged ;
tgt_text.99: and a conqueroi usually had humanities and privileges conferred upon him by the grati­ tude of his fellow citizens.
tgt_text.100: On his return home the victor entered the city in a triumphal procession, in which his praises were celebrated, frequently in the loftiest strains of poetry.
tgt_text.101: The Olympic games were celebrated once in four years.
tgt_text.102: They lasted for five days, and terminated on the full moon which succeeded the summer solstice.
tgt_text.103: Contrasted with the particular eras which served for the chronological arrange­ ment of events in distinct provinces of Greece, the epoch supplied by their celebration to all the inhabitants of the Hellenic soil deserves peculiar attention.
tgt_text.104: While the suc­ cession of Priestesses of Juno at Argos, while the Ephors at Sparta, and the Archons at Athens, furnished to those states respectively the basis of their chronological systems ;
tgt_text.105: it was not a personage invested with a civil or sacerdotal character, who gave his name, not merely to the single years, but to the quadrennial periods of the whole of Greece;
tgt_text.106: it was he who was proclaimed victor, not in the chariot race of the Hippodrome, but as having outrun his rivals in the stadium at Olympia.
tgt_text.107: A reflection on the rapid course of time (the great racer in the stadium of the world) might well be suggested by such a practice;
tgt_text.108: but it is more remarkable, as illustrating the regard paid, by the unanimous consent of all the states of Greece, to those exercises of physical force, which preserved them so long from the corruptions of luxury and effeminacy, into which, through their growing opulence and familiarity with oriental habits, they would very soon otherwise have fallen.
tgt_text.109: Olympia was the Palæstra of all Greece.
tgt_text.110: The simplicity of the prizes, the antiquity of their institution, the sacred ceremonies with which they were conducted ;
tgt_text.111: the glory which attached not merely to the victor, but to his parents.
tgt_text.113: his canonization in the Greek calendar;
tgt_text.114: the concourse of rival tribes from every quarter of the Greek continent and peninsula to behold the contests and to applaud the conqueror ;
tgt_text.116: the garlands showered upon his head by the hands of friends, of strangers, and of Greece herself;
tgt_text.117: the statue erected to him in the precincts of the consecrated grove, by the side of princes, of heroes, and of gods;
tgt_text.118: the very rareness of the celebration, and the glories of the season of the year at which it took place, when all the charms of summer were poured upon the earth by day, and the full orb of the moon streamed upon the olive groves, and the broad flood of the Alpheius by night;
tgt_text.119: these were influences which, while they seemed to raise the individual to an elevation more than human, pro­ duced a far more noble and useful result than this,-that of maintaining in the nation a general respect for a manly and intrepid character, and of supporting that moral dignity and independence, which so long resisted the aggressions of force from without, and were proof against the contagion of weak and licentious principles within.
tgt_text.120: Inscribed to Hiero of Syracuse, victorious in the single horse-race :
tgt_text.122: and sung at Syracuse, at a banquet in the palace.
tgt_text.125: The poet prepares a hymn in honour of king Hiero, for his victory in the Olympic games.
tgt_text.127: Digression from the mention of Olympia to the fable of Pelops, and the tale of Tantalus’s crime and its punishment.
tgt_text.129: Return to the praise of Hiero ;
tgt_text.131: BEST of all things is water, and gold shines far above all haughty wealth as blazing fire shines in the night;
tgt_text.132: but if thou wishest to tell of victories, my heart, seek no bright star during the day, in the desert air, more genial than the sun;
tgt_text.133: nor can we sing of a contest higher in rank than Olympia's, whence the renowned hymn has power over the minds of the wise, so that they sing the Son of Cronos, coming to the blest wealthy dwelling of Hiero—who wields the righteous sceptre in Sicily rich in sheep, plucking the highest of all virtues ;
tgt_text.134: a and he is adorned also with the flower of music, in such strains as we poets round the hospitable table often sing.
tgt_text.135: But from the peg take down the Dorian lyre, if at all the glory of Pisa and Pherenicus hath subjected thy mind to the influence of sweetest thoughts, when by the Alpheus he rushed, displaying in the course a body ungoaded, and blended with victory his lord, the Syracusian monarch re­ joicing in the steed.
tgt_text.136: And for him (the monarch) glory shines in Lydian Pelops' colony abounding in brave men [i. e. in Pisa],—Pelops, whom earth-surrounding Poseidon of mighty strength loved from the time when Clotho raised him from the unsullied urn,b well furnished as to his resplendent shoulder with ivory.
tgt_text.137: Surely many things are wonderful, and in these sometimes fables, adorned beyond the truth with varied falsehoods, deceive tte report of mortals.c
tgt_text.138: And tho Grace, that procureth all the sweets for mortals, bestowing authority bath brought about that the incredible should often come to be believed;
tgt_text.139: but after-days are the best con­ vincers.
tgt_text.140: Now it is becoming to a man to speak what is good con­ cerning the deities, for so is blame the less.
tgt_text.141: 0 son of Tan­ talus, I will record thy story, not as men of yore have done, how when thy sire invited the gods to that most holy ban­ quet, and to friendly Sipylus, offering a return of feasts to the gods, then that he of the bright trident seized thee, and, tamed in his soul by love, bore thee away on his gold-decked steeds to the palace of Zeus the far-honoured, where in after­ time came Ganymede to the same office.
tgt_text.142: But when thou hadst vanished, nor did the men, after much search, bring thee to thy mother, forthwith did some one of the envious neighbours say that the gods had cut thee limb by limb intod the strength of water boiling with fire, and on the tables around they distributed among themselves the sodden morsels of thy flesh, and ate.
tgt_text.143: But to me it is impossible to call any of the blessed ones a glutton;
tgt_text.144: I stand aloof from such a thought.
tgt_text.145: Losse often befalls the slander­ ous.
tgt_text.146: But, yet, if the guardians of Olympus honoured any mortal man, it was this Tantalus;
tgt_text.147: but he could not bear meekly great prosperity;
tgt_text.148: but through pride and surfeit drew upon himself immense calamity, which the Father hung over him, a mighty stone for him, which ever eagerly desiring to remove from his head, he is a stranger to happiness.
tgt_text.149: This helpless constantly-wretched life he has, a fourth affliction with three others, because that having stolen the nectar and ambrosia of the immortals with which they had made him imperishable, he gave it to his comrade boon companions;
tgt_text.150: but if any one expects to escape the notice of the Deity in doing aught, he errs.
tgt_text.151: Therefore the immortals sent back his son again to the short-lived race of men.
tgt_text.152: But when, about the time of blooming youth, down began to shade his chin so as to make it dark, he meditated to obtain in contest the proffered marriage, the renowned Hippodameia, from her Plan sire.

tgt_text.709: PYTHIAN games (Πύθια), one of the four great national festivals of the Greeks.
tgt_text.710: It was celebrated in the neighbour­ hood of Delphi, anciently called Pytho, in honour of Apollo, Artemis, and Leto.
tgt_text.711: The place of this solemnity was the Crisscean plain, which for this purpose contained a hippo­ dromus, or race-course, a stadium of 1,000 feet in length.
tgt_text.712: and a theatre in which the musical contests took place A gymnasium, prytaneum, and other buildings of this kind, probably existed here, as at Olympia, although they are not mentioned.
tgt_text.713: Once the Pythian games were held at Athens on the advice of Demetrius Poliorcetes, because Ætolians were in possession of the passes around Delphi.
tgt_text.714: The Pythian games were, according to most legends, insti­ tuted by Apollo himself;
tgt_text.715: other traditions referred them to the ancient heroes, such as Amphictyon, Adrastus, Diomedes, and others.
tgt_text.716: They were originally, perhaps, nothing more than a religious panegyris, occasioned by the oracle of Delphi;
tgt_text.717: and the sacred games are said to have been at first only a musical contest, which consisted in singing a hymn in honour of the Pythian god, with the accompaniment of the cithara.
tgt_text.718: Some of the poets, however, and mythographers represent even the gods and the early heroes as engaged in gymnastic and equestrian contests at the Pythian games.
tgt_text.719: But such statements, numerous as they are, can prove no­ thing :
tgt_text.720: they are anachronisms, in which late writers were fond of indulging.
tgt_text.721: The description of the Pythian games in which Sophocles, in the Electra, makes Orestes take part, belongs to this class.
tgt_text.722: The Pythian games must, on account of the celebrity of the Delphic oracle, have become a national festival for all the Greeks at a very early period;
tgt_text.723: and when Solon fixed pecuniary rewards for those Athenians who were victims in the great national festivals, the Pythian agon was undoubtedly included in the number, though it is not expressly mentioned.
tgt_text.724: Whether gymnastic contests had been performed at the Pythian games previous to 01.
tgt_text.726: Böckh supposes that these two kinds of games had been connected at the Pythia from early times, but that after­ wards the gymnastic games were neglected :
tgt_text.727: but, however this may be, it is certain that about Olympiad 47 they did not exist at Delphi Down to Olympiad 48 the Delphians themselves had been the agonothetæ at the Pythian games;
tgt_text.728: but in the third year of this Olympiad, when, after the Crissœan war, the A mphictyons took the management under their care, they naturally became the agonothetæ.
tgt_text.729: Some of the ancients date the institution of the Pythian games from this time, and others say that henceforth they were called Pythian games.
tgt_text.730: Owing to their being under the management of Amphictyons, they are sometimes called ’Αμφικτυονικὰ ἆθλα.
tgt_text.731: From Olympiad 48, 3, the Pythiads were occasionally used as an era, and the first celebration under the Amphictyons was the first Pythiad.
tgt_text.732: Pausanias expressly states that in this year the original musical contest in Κιθαρωδία was ex­ tended by the addition of αὐλω̨ ;
tgt_text.733: i. e. singing with the accompaniment of the flute, and by that of flute-playing alone.
tgt_text.734: Strabo, in speaking of these innovations, does not mention the αὐλω̨δία, but states that the contest of cithara- players (κιθαρισταί) was added;
tgt_text.735: while Pausanias assigns the introduction of this contest to the eighth Pythiad.
tgt_text.736: One of the musical contests at the Pythian games in which only flute and cithara-players took part, was the so-called νόμος πυθικός ;
tgt_text.737: which, at least in subsequent times, con­ sisted of five parts ;
tgt_text.738: viz., ἀνάκρουσις, ἄμπειρα, κατακελευσμὸς, ἲαμβοι καὶ δάκτυλοι, and σύο̡ιγγες.
tgt_text.739: The whole of this νόμος was a musical description of the fight of Apollo with the dragon, and of his victory over the monster.
tgt_text.740: A somewhat different account of the parts of this νόμος is given by the scholiast on Pindar, and by Pollux.
tgt_text.741: Besides these innovations in the musical contests which were made in the first Pythiad, such gymnastic and eques­ trian games as were then customary at Olympia, were either revived at Delphi, or introduced for the first time.
tgt_text.742: The chariot-race with four horses was not introduced till the second Pythiad.
tgt_text.743: Some games on the other hand wero adopted, which had not yet been practised at Olympia;
tgt_text.744: viz., the δολιχός, and the δίαυλος, for boys.
tgt_text.745: In the first Pythiad the victors received χρήματα as their prize, but in the second a chaplet was established as the reward for the victors.
tgt_text.746: The scholiasts on Pindar reckon the first Pythiad from this introduction of the chaplet, and their system has been followed by most modern chronologerg, though Pausanias expressly assigns this institution to the second Pythiad.
tgt_text.747: The αὐλω̨δία, which was introduced in the first Pythiad, was omitted at the second, and ever after, as only elegies and θρη̃νοι had been sung to the flute, which were thought too melancholy for this solemnity.
tgt_text.748: The τεθρίππος, or chariot-race with four horses, however, was added in the same Pythiad.
tgt_text.749: In the eighth Pythiad (Olym­ piad 55, 3) the contest in playing the cithara without singing was introduced;
tgt_text.750: in Pythiad 23, the foot-race in arms was added ;
tgt_text.751: in Pythiad 48, the chariot-race with two full-grown horses (συνώριδος δρόμος) was performed for the first time;
tgt_text.752: in Pythiad 53, the chariot-race with four foals was intro­ duced ;
tgt_text.753: in Pythiad 61, the pancratium for boys :
tgt_text.754: in Pythiad 53, the horse-race with foals;
tgt_text.755: and in Pythiad 69, the chariot- race with two foals was introduced.
tgt_text.756: Various musical con tests were also added in the course of time ;
tgt_text.757: and contests in tragedy, as well as in other kinds of poetry, and in recitations of historical compositions, are expressly mentioned.
tgt_text.758: Works of art, as paintings and sculptures, were exhibited to the assembled Greeks, and prizes were awarded to those who had produced the finest works.
tgt_text.759: The musical and artistic contests were at all times the most prominent feature of the Pythian games, and in this respect they even excelled the Olympic games.
tgt_text.760: Previous to Olympiad 48, the Pythian games had been an ἐνναετηρίς ;
tgt_text.761: that is, they had been celebrated at the end of every eighth year;
tgt_text.762: but in Olympiad 48, 3, they became, like the Olympia, a πενταετηρίς ;
tgt_text.763: i. e., they were held at the end of every fourth year ;
tgt_text.764: and a Pythiad, therefore, ever since the time that it was used as an era, comprehended a space of four years, commencing with the third year of every Olympiad.
tgt_text.765: Others have, in opposition to direct statements, inferred from Thucydides that the Pythian games were held towards the end of the second year of every Olympiad.
tgt_text.766: As for the season of the Pythian games, they were in all probability held in the spring, and most writers believe that it was held in the month of Bysius, which is supposed to be the same as the Attic Munychion.
tgt_text.767: Böckh, however, has shown that the games took place in the month of Bucatius, which followed after the month of Bysius, and that this month must be considered the same as the Attic Muny­ chion.
tgt_text.768: The games lasted for several days, as is expressly mentioned by Sophocles, but we do not know how many
tgt_text.769: Then ancient writers speak of the day of the Pythian gon, they are probably thinking of the musical agon alone, which was the .'ost important part of the games, and pro­ bably took place on the 7th of Bucatius.
tgt_text.770: It is quite impos- Bible to conceive that all the numerous games should have taken place on one day.
tgt_text.771: The concourse of strangers at the season of this panegyris must have been very great, as undoubtedly all the Greeks were allowed to attend.
tgt_text.772: The states belonging to the Am­ phictyony of Delphi had to send their theori in the month of Bysius, some time before the commencement of the festival itself.
tgt_text.773: All theori sent by the Greeks to Delphi, on this occasion, were called Πυθαἲσταί, and the theories sent by the Athenians were all particularly brilliant.
tgt_text.774: As regards sacrifices, processions, and other solemnities, it may be pre­ sumed that they resembled, in a great measure, those of Olympia.
tgt_text.775: A splendid, though probably in some degree fictitious, description of a theoria of Thessalians may be read in Heliodorus.
tgt_text.776: As to the order in which the various games were per­ formed, scarcely anything is known, with the exception of some allusions in Pindar, and a few remarks in Plutarch.
tgt_text.777: The latter says, that the musical contests preceded the gymnastic contests ;
tgt_text.778: and from Sophocles, it is clear that gymnastic contests preceded the horse and chariot-races.
tgt_text.779: Every game, moreover, which was performed by men and boys, was always first performed by the latter.
tgt_text.780: We have stated above, that down to Olympiad 48, the Delphians had the management of the Pythian games;
tgt_text.781: but of the manner in which they were conducted previous to that time nothing is known.
tgt_text.782: When they came under 1 he care of the Amphictyons, especial persons were appointed for the purpose of conducting the games, and of acting as judges
tgt_text.783: They were called ’Επιμεληταί, and answered to the Olympian Hellanodicæ.
tgt_text.785: In later times it was decreed by the Amphictyons, that king Philip, with the Thessalians and Bœotians, should undertake the management of the games;
tgt_text.786: but afterwards, and even under tLe Roman emperors, the Amphictyons again appeared in the possession of this privilege.
tgt_text.787: The ίατηλεμιπἐ had to maintain peace and order, and were assisted by μαστιγοφόροι, who executed any punishment at their command, and thus answered to the Olympian ἀλυταί.
tgt_text.788: The prize given to the victors in the Pythian games was, from the time of the second Pythiad, a laurel chaplet;
tgt_text.789: so that they then became an ἀγὼν στεφανίτης, while before they had been ἀγὼν χο̡η­ ματίτης.
tgt_text.790: In addition to this chaplet, the victor here, as at Olympia, received the symbolic palm-branch, and was allowed to have his own statue erected in the Crissæan plain.
tgt_text.791: The time when the Pythian games ceased to be solemnized is not certain;
tgt_text.792: but they probably lasted as long as the Olympic games, i. e. down to the year A.D. 394.
tgt_text.793: In A.D. 191, a celebration of the Pythia is mentioned by Philostratus;
tgt_text.794: and in the time of the emperor Julian, they still continued to be held, as is manifest from his own words.
tgt_text.795: Pythian games of less importance were celebrated in a great many other places, where the worship of Apollo was introduced;
tgt_text.796: and the games of Delphi are sometimes distinguished from these lesser Pythia by the addition of the words iv Δελφοĩς.
tgt_text.797: But, as by far the greater number of the lesser Pythia are not mentioned in the extant ancient writers, and are only known from coins or inscriptions, we shall only give a list of the places where they were held:

tgt_text.1519: NEMEAN Games (νέμεα, νεμει̃α, or νεμαι̃α), one of the four great national festivals of the Greeks.
tgt_text.1520: It was held at Nemea, a place near Cleonæ in Argolis.
tgt_text.1521: The various legends respecting its origin are related in the arguments of the Scholiasts to the Nemea of Pindar, with which may be compared Pausanias and Apollodorus.
tgt_text.1522: All these legends, however, agre< in stating, that the Nemea were originally instituted by the Seven against Thebes, in commemoration of the death of Opheltes, afterwards called Archemorus.
tgt_text.1523: When the Seven arrived at Nemea, and were very thirsty, they met Hypsipyle, who was carrying Opheltes, the child of the priest of Zeus and of Eurydice.
tgt_text.1524: While she showed to the heroes the way to the nearest well, she left the child behind, lying in a meadow, which during her absence was killed by a dragon.
tgt_text.1525: When the Seven on their return saw the accident, they slew the dragon, and instituted funeral games (ἀγὼν ἐπιτάϕιος), to be held every third year (τριετηρικός).
tgt_text.1526: Other legends attribute the institution of the Nemean Games to Heracles, after he had slain the Nemean lion ;
tgt_text.1527: but the more genuine tradition was, that he had either revived the ancient games, or at least introduced the alteration by which they were from this time celebrated in honour of Zeus.
tgt_text.1528: That Zeus was the god in honour of whom the games were afterwards celebrated, is stated by Pindar.
tgt_text.1529: The games wer" at l.rst of a warlike character, and only warriors and their sons were allowed to take part in them ;
tgt_text.1530: subsequently, however, they were thrown open to all the Greeks.
tgt_text.1531: The games took place in a grove between Cleonæ and Phlius.
tgt_text.1532: The various games, according to the enumeration of Apollodorus, were horse-racing, running in armour in the stadium, wrestling, chariot-racing, and discus, boxing, throwing the spear, and shooting with the bow, to which we may add musical contests.
tgt_text.1533: The Scholiasts on Pindar describe the agon very imperfectly as ίππικός and γυμνικός.
tgt_text.1534: The prize given to the victors was at first a chaplet of olive branches, but afterwards a chaplet of green parsley.
tgt_text.1535: When this alteration was introduced, is not certain, though it may be inferred from an expression of Pindar, who calls the parsley (σέλινον) the βοτάνα λεόντος, that the new prize was believed to have been introduced by Heracles.
tgt_text.1536: The presidency at these games, and the management of them, belonged at different times to Cleonæ, (Cormth, and Argos, and from the first of these places they are sometimes called ἀγων Κλεώναιος.
tgt_text.1537: The judges who awarded the prizes were dressed in black robes, and an instance of their justice, when the Argives presided, is recorded by Pausanias.
tgt_text.1538: Respecting the time at which the Nemean Games were held, the Scholiast on Pindar merely states that they were held on the 12th of the month of Panemus, though in another passage he makes a statement which upsets this assertion.
tgt_text.1539: Pausanias speaks of Winter N emea, and manifestly distin­ guishes them from others which were held in summer.
tgt_text.1540: It seems that for a time the celebration of the Nemea was neglected, and that they were revived in Olympiad 53, 2, from which time Eusebius dates the first Nemead.
tgt_text.1541: Hence­ forth it is certain they were for a long time celebrated regularly twice in every Olympiad, viz.
tgt_text.1542: at the commence­ ment of every second Olympic year in the winter, and soon atter the commencement of every fourth Olympic year in the summer About the time of the battle of Marathon it became customary in Argolis to reckon according to Nemeads.
tgt_text.1543: In 208 B.C. Philip of Macedonia was honoured by the Argives with the presidency of the Nemean Games, and Quinctius Flaminius proclaimed at the Nemea the freedom of the Argives.
tgt_text.1544: The Emperor Hadrian restored the horse- racing of boys at the Nemea, which had fallen into disuse ;
tgt_text.1545: but after his time they do not seem to have been much longer celebrated, as they are no longer mentioned by any of the writers of the subsequent period.

tgt_text.2094: ISTHMIAN GAMES (῎Ισθμια), one of the four great national festivals of the Greeks.
tgt_text.2095: This festival derived its name from the Corinthian isthmus, where it was held.
tgt_text.2096: Where the isthmus is narrowest, between the coast of the Saronic gulf and the western foot of the Œnean hills, was the temple of Poseidon, and near it was a theatre and a stadium, of white marble.
tgt_text.2097: The entrance to the temple was adorned with an avenue of statues of the victors in the Isthmian games, and with groves of pine-trees.
tgt_text.2098: These games were said originally to have been instituted by Sisyphus in honour of Melicertes, who was also called Palæmon.
tgt_text.2099: Their original mode of celebration partook, as Plutarch remarks, more of the character of mysteries, than of a great and national assembly, with its various amusements, and was performed at night.
tgt_text.2100: Subsequent to the age of Theseus, the Isthmia were celebrated in honour of Poseidon;
tgt_text.2101: and this innovation is ascribed to Theseus himself, who, accord­ ing to some legends, was a son of Poseidon, and who, in the institution of the new Isthmian solemnities, is said to have imitated Heracles, the founder of the Olympian games.
tgt_text.2102: The celebration of the Isthmia was henceforth con­ ducted by the Corinthians, but Theseus had reserved for his Athenians some honourable distinctions;
tgt_text.2103: those Athenians who attended the Isthmia sailed across the Saronic gulf in a sacred vessel (θεωρις), and an honorary place (προεδρία) as large as the sail of their vessel was assigned to them during the celebration of the games.
tgt_text.2104: In times of war between the two states, a sacred truce was concluded, and the Athenians were invited to attend at the solemnities.
tgt_text.2105: The Eleans did not take part in the games, and various stories were related to account for this singular circumstance.
tgt_text.2106: It is a very probable conjecture of Wachsmuth, that the Isthmia, after the changes ascribed to Theseus, were merely a panegyris of the Ionians of Peloponnesus and those of Attica;
tgt_text.2107: for it should be observed, that Posei­ don was an Ionian deity, whose worship appears originally to have been unknown to the Dorians.
tgt_text.2108: During the reign of the Cypselids at Corinth, the celebration of the Isthmian games was suspended for seventy years:
tgt_text.2109: but after this time they gradually rose to the rank of a national festival of all the Greeks.
tgt_text.2110: In Olympiad 49 they became periodical, and were menceforth celebrated regularly every third year, twice in every Olympiad, that is, in the first and third year of every Olympiad.
tgt_text.2111: The Isthmia held in the first year of an Olympiad fell in the Corinthian month Panemus (the Attic Hecatombæon);
tgt_text.2112: and those which were held in the third year of an Olympiad, fell either in the month of Munychion or Thargelion.
tgt_text.2113: Pliny and Solinus erroneously state that the Isthmia were celebrated every fifth year.
tgt_text.2114: With this regularity the solemnities continued to be held by the Greeks down to a very late period.
tgt_text.2115: In 228 B. c. the Romans were allowed the privilege of taking part in the Isthmia ;
tgt_text.2116: and it was in this solemnity, that, in 196 B.c., Flaminius proclaimed before an innumerable assembly the i tide­ pendence of Greece.
tgt_text.2117: After the fall of Corinth in 146 B.C., the Sicyonians were honoured with the privilege of con­ ducting the Isthmian games;
tgt_text.2118: but when the town of Corinth as rebuilt by Julius Cæsar, the right of conducting the solemnities was restored to the Corinthians, and it seems that they henceforth continued to be celebrated, till Christianity became the state religion of the Roman empire.
tgt_text.2119: The season of the Isthmian solemnities was like that of all the great national festivals, distinguished by general rejoicings and feasting.
tgt_text.2120: The contests and games of the Isthmia were the same as those at Olympia, and embraced all the varieties of athletic performances, such as wrestling, the pancratium, together with horse and chariot-racing.
tgt_text.2121: Musical and poetical per­ formances were likewise carried on, and in the latter women were also allowed to take part, as we must infer from Plutarch;
tgt_text.2122: who, on the authority of Polemo, states, that in the treasury in Sicyon there was a golden book which had been presented to it by Aristomache, the poetess, after she had gained the victory at the Isthmia.
tgt_text.2123: At a late period of the Roman empire, the character of the games at the Isthmia appears greatly altered;
tgt_text.2124: for, in the letter of the Emperor Julian, it is stated that the Corinthians purchased bears and panthers for the purpose of exhibiting their fights at the Isthmia;
tgt_text.2125: and it is not improbable that the custom of intro­ ducing fights of animals on this occasion commenced soon after the time of Cæsar.
tgt_text.2126: The prize of a victor in the Isthmian games consisted at first of a garland of pine-leaves, and after­ wards of a wreath of ivy ;
tgt_text.2127: but in the end the ivy was again superseded by a pine-garland.
tgt_text.2128: Simple as such a reward was, a victor in the games gained the greatest distinction and honour among his countrymen;
tgt_text.2129: and a victory not only rendered the individual who obtained it a subject of admira­ tion, but shed lustre over his family, and the whole town or community to which he belonged.
tgt_text.2130: Hence, Solon established by a law, that eveiy Athenian who gained the victory at the Isthmian games, should receive from the public treasury a reward of one hundred drachmae.

tgt_text.2213: The poet commemorates the latter, and the relationship of the conqueror to the wealthy house of the Labdacidæ.
tgt_text.2215: The praises of the Cleonymidæ, the family of the conqueror ;

tgt_text.2221: IF any man being successful either in glorious games or in abundance of wealth, sets bounds in his soul to wearisome insolence, he is worthy to be mingled with a the praises of the citizens.

tgt_text.2271: Inscribed to Phylacidas, son of Lampo, of Ægina, victorious in the pancratium at the Isthmian games :

tgt_text.2275: Invocation and power of Theia (also called Chryse), the goddess of wealth.
tgt_text.2277: Praise of the three victories won by Phylacidas, and of the one won by his brother Pytheas.
tgt_text.2279: The praises of the achievements in war of Ægina, the mythical deeds of the Æacidæ at Troy, and the lately-won glory of the Æginetan fleet at Salamis.

tgt_text.2283: O THEIA, mother of the sun, worshipped under many titles, through thee it is that men esteem potent gold far beyond all other things;

tgt_text.2315: This ode is prior in time to the foregoing one (but later than Nemea V.), and was composed undoubtedly before the battle of Salamis, and sung at Ægina at a banquet in the house of Lampo, the victor's father.
tgt_text.2318: The poet expresses his hope that he may hereafter be able to compose a third ode, this being the second (and Nemean V. the first), in honour of the sons of Lampo, for a future Olympian victory;

tgt_text.2325: The poet returns to the subject of the ode, the praises of the victor, of Pytheas his brother, of Euthy­ menes his uncle, and of Lampo his father, who had so successfully trained his two sons for their contests in the games.

tgt_text.2367: The ancient and mythical glories of Thebes.

tgt_text.2371: The poet exhorts his fellow-citizens to moderation in time of prosperity, and warns them against striving after what is beyond their reach, and out of their power to effect.
tgt_text.2372: WITH which of thy former native glories, 0 blessed Theba, hast thou most specially delighted thy soul ?
tgt_text.2373: Was it when thou broughtest to light the assessor of timbrilled Demeter, Dionysus of the floating locks?
tgt_text.2374: or was it when, receiving at the mid hour of night the mightiest of the gods snowing with gold, what time, standing within the doors of Amphi­ tryon, he approached his wife with Heraclean seed ?
tgt_text.2375: or was it when thou didst rejoice at the sage counsels of Tiresias ?
tgt_text.2376: or when in Iolaus skilled in the steed ?
tgt_text.2377: or in the seed of the dragon's teeth who are unwearied at the spear ?
tgt_text.2378: or was it when, from the fierce battle, thou didst send back Adrastus bereft of innumerable companions to equestrian Argos ?
tgt_text.2379: or when thou placedst on firm basea the Dorian colony of the Lacedæmonians, and the Ægidæ thy descendants took Amyclæ, through the Pythian oracles ?

tgt_text.2400: Inscribed to Oleander of Ægina, son of Telesarchus, victorious in the pancratium at the Isthmian and Nemeau games :
tgt_text.2401: written a few monthe after the battle of Platæa, 01. 75, 2,—B.C. 479 :
tgt_text.2403: Boeckh thinks that the ode must have been written shortly after the taking of Thebes by the allied Greeks, and therefore that it comme­ morates a Nemean, and not an Isthmian victory.
tgt_text.2406: The poet, though anxious and fearful of some new disaster after the close, it would seem, of the Persian war, when the Thebans feared the vengeance of the allied Greeks for their late Medizing, yet rouses himself to sing the victories of Oleander.
tgt_text.2408: The mythical portion of the ode, commencing with the mythical con­ nection of Thebes and Ægina.
tgt_text.2409: Pindar passes on to the fame of Æacus as an arbitrator in disputes and quarrels;
tgt_text.2410: to the Æacidæ, distin­ guished for valour and for justice ;
tgt_text.2411: to the tale of the wedding of Peleus and Thetis, whose hand was sought by Zeus and Poseidon ;
tgt_text.2412: and to the valiant deeds of Achilles at Troy.
tgt_text.2414: The poet returns to the immediate subject of his ode, the victories in the games of Nicocles, the late uncle of the conqueror, and the present victory of Oleander.
tgt_text.2415: FOR Oleander and his youthful prime let some one, 0 ye youths, going to the splendid vestibule of his father Te­ lesarchus, raise the festal song, the glorious recompense of his toils, the reward both of his Isthmian victory, and because that, in Nemea, he gained the victory in the contest.
tgt_text.2416: For whom I too, though grieved in soul, am bidden to invoke the golden Muse.
tgt_text.2417: But since we have been freed from mighty woes, let us neither fall into a lack of crowns, nor do thou, my spirit, cherish thy woes;
tgt_text.2418: but having ceased from unprofitable griefs, let us sportively utter abroad some sweet strain even after our calamity :
tgt_text.2419: since some deity hath turned aside from us the stone of Tantalus that was hung over our head, insufferable toil to Greece.
tgt_text.2420: But the passing away of my fear has put an end to my grievous anxiety, and it is better always to look to what is present.
tgt_text.2421: For deceitful time hanga over men, rolling life's stream along ;

tgt_text.2425: Who near Dirce of the fair stream gave one to dwell as mistress of the city that loves the car ;

tgt_text.2427: where to his loud-thundering sire thou didst bring forth divine Æacus the most wise of all the dwellers upon earth, who used to bring to an end the strifes even of the gods:
tgt_text.2428: his godlike sons and his warlike sons’ sons excelled by their courage in conducting the din of brazen mournful war, and they were temperate-minded and sage of soul.
tgt_text.2429: This did the assemblies of the blessed ones remember, when Zeus and bright Poseidon strove for the nuptial tie of Thetis, either of them desiring that she should be his fair bride ;
tgt_text.2431: But the immortal understandings of the other gods accom­ plished not for them that wedlock, when they heard the voice of the oracles.
tgt_text.2432: For Themis, author of wise counsel, said amongst them all, that it was fated that the ocean goddess should bring forth for himc a lordly son more mighty than his sire, who should wield in his hand another weapon more powerful than the thunderbolt and the irresistible trident, if she were united to Zeus or to the brothers of Zeus.—“
tgt_text.2433: But do you then cease this strife, and let her, having obtained a mortal spouse, behold her son slain in war, like to Ares in might, and in strength of feet like lightning.
